vectorField.invertSymbolsTip:
Đ_Draw the symbols in the opposite direction_______________________ớ.
Đ_By default, the symbols are displayed in the direction defined by the data. If the angle direction in the data is measured based on the beginning of the mass flow, such as wind, use this option to invert the vector symbol direction_____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.

arcade.defaultExpressionScript_line1: Đ_Write a script that returns a value that will be used to draw features_____________________________________ớ.
arcade.defaultExpressionScript_line2: Đ_For example, find the percentage of oak trees________________________ớ:

tooltips.title: Đ_When to use ${title}_____________________ớ
tooltips.color: Đ_Use colors to represent your numeric or ranked data. Choose a theme that matches your data to a particular color scheme. For example, show data like age or income with the High-to-low theme that uses a simple light to dark color scheme_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.colorDate: Đ_Use colors to represent your date data. Choose a theme that matches your data to a particular color scheme. For example, show data like age or income with the Above and Below theme that centers the ramp on a meaningful value such as an average or a goal________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.colorAge: Đ_Use colors to represent the age of features. Age reflects the length of time from a start date to an end date. For example, show features less than 30 days old as green and more than 90 days old as red______________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.size: Đ_Use different symbol sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data. The larger the symbol, the bigger the data value____________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.sizeDate: Đ_Use different symbol sizes to represent your date data. For example, larger symbols could represent newer dates_________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.sizeAge: Đ_Use size to represent the age of features. Age reflects the length of time from a start date to an end date. For example, show data like new crimes with a large symbol and have the symbol decrease in size until it is 90 days old____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.type: Đ_Show different categories of features — such as type of tree, road class, or province name — with different colors. Some categories will not have an inherent order. For categories that do, such as educational attainment and income, consider using a sequential color ramp to visualize ranked categories________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.typeDate: Đ_Show different categories of features — such as years or days — with different colors____________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.color_Size: Đ_The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your numeric or ranked data. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data. This map style works particularly well when the first attribute is a rate, ratio, percent, index or similar type of data_____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.color_SizeDate: Đ_The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your numeric or ranked data. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your date data as a continuous timeline______________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.color_SizeAge: Đ_The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your numeric or ranked data. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent the age of features____________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.colorDate_Size: Đ_The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your date data as a continuous timeline. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data______________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.colorDate_SizeDate: Đ_The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your date data as a continuous timeline. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your date data as a continuous timeline____________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.colorDate_SizeAge: Đ_The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your date data as a continuous timeline. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent the age of features__________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.colorAge_Size: Đ_The first attribute you choose uses color to represent the age of features. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data____________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.colorAge_SizeDate: Đ_The first attribute you choose uses color to represent the age of features. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your date data as a continuous timeline__________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.type_Size: Đ_The first attribute you choose categorizes your data based on the unique values found, and uses color to distinguish them on the map. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.type_SizeDate: Đ_The first attribute you choose categorizes your data based on the unique values found, and uses color to distinguish them on the map. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your date data as a continuous timeline_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.typeDate_Size: Đ_The first attribute you choose categorizes your date data based on the unique values found, and uses color to distinguish them on the map. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your data___________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.type_SizeAge: Đ_The first attribute you choose categorizes your data based on the unique values found, and uses color to distinguish them on the map. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent the age of features_____________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.predominance: Đ_Compare attributes that share a common subject and unit of measurement to see which has the highest value. Example: choose Corn Acres, Wheat Acres, and Cotton Acres to see which is the predominant crop in each area. Color shows the predominant category and transparency shows the relative strength of the predominance________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.predominanceSize: Đ_Compare attributes that share a common subject and unit of measurement to see which has the highest value. Example: choose Corn Acres, Wheat Acres, and Cotton Acres to see which is the predominant crop in each area. Color shows the predominant category, size shows the sum of the categories, and transparency shows the relative strength of the predominance____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.sizeForPredominance: Đ_Use different symbol sizes to represent the sum of all categories. The larger the symbol, the bigger the value_________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.chart: Đ_Compare the relative abundance of different categories of things at locations. Example: compare the relative proportions of different age generations in a country or state (gen-z, millenials, gen-x, and boomers)___________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.chartSize: Đ_Compare the relative abundance of different categories of things at locations and use size to capture the total amount or magnitude. Example: compare the relative proportions of different crop types (corn, wheat, soy beans, cotton) while the overall size of the pie depicts how much total crops are harvested____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.relationship: Đ_Use hybrid colors to view the relationship between two numeric attributes. Each attribute uses a distinct sequential color scheme to represent its classified data. Both schemes converge, allowing you to view and explore where the attributes may be related_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.relationshipSize: Đ_Use hybrid colors to view the relationship between the first two numeric attributes. The third attribute uses different sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data_____________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.location: Đ_Show the geographic boundaries, lines, or point locations of your data_____________________________________ớ.
tooltips.dotDensity: Đ_Use dot density to visualize the distribution of one attribute or compare multiple attributes. Choose the quantity that each dot represents. Example: 1 dot represents 1,000 people or 1 dot represents 20 trees__________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.heatMap: Đ_Show areas of high activity with stronger colors that appear to glow hotter_______________________________________ớ.
tooltips.compare: Đ_The first attribute is compared to the second attribute, and represented as a simple ratio, or as "A as a percent of B", or as "A as a percent of A+B." Examples: Revenue / Cost of Sale, or Corn Acres / Total Acres, or Corn Acres / (Corn + Wheat Acres)_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.stretch: Đ_Use a stretch renderer to enhance the visual contrast of data for analysis. An appropriate stretch renderer can enhance the contrast of imagery, allowing the user to control how their data is displayed for efficient imagery analysis______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.rgb: Đ_An RGB renderer is used to adjust the color bands of a multispectral image. Apply an RGB renderer to a layer to enhance feature visibility_______________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.classify: Đ_The Classify renderer displays thematic data by grouping cell values into classes. Use this type of thematic classification on continuous phenomena, such as slope, distance, or suitability, where you want to classify the range into a small number of classes and assign colors to those classes____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.uniqueValues: Đ_The Unique Values renderer is used to display each value in the image layer individually. For instance, you might have discrete categories representing particular objects on the earth's surface, such as those in a thematic layer, which could display soil types or land use__________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.shadedRelief: Đ_Shaded relief renderer produces a grayscale or colored 3D representation of the surface on a layer, with the sun's relative position taken into account for shading the image. This renderer uses a hillshading technique for visualizing terrain determined by a light source and the slope and aspect of the elevation surface__________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.vectorField: Đ_Use Vector field renderer to visualize flow direction and magnitude information in your raster with vector symbols___________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.colormap: Đ_A colormap renderer displays single-band thematic data based on specific colors, aiding in visual analysis of the data. Like the unique values renderer, the colormap renderer should be used to differentiate between classes or categories, but with a set of predefined colors from the associated colormap_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ớ.
tooltips.flow: Đ_Motion helps to highlight both the direction and magnitude of flow in a field. Apply blend modes or layer effects to further enhance the lines_________________________________________________________________________ớ.

transparency.transparencyLabel: Đ_Set transparency based on attribute values______________________ớ
transparency.transparencyLabelPredominance: Đ_Set transparency based on the predominant percentage___________________________ớ

errors.expressionMustBeNumber: Đ_The expression must return a number value______________________ớ.

rotation.rotationLabel: Đ_Rotate symbols based on attribute values_____________________ớ

themeButton.highToLowMsg: Đ_Vary the size of features from high to low_______________________ớ.
themeButton.aboveMsg: Đ_Emphasize data above a key value like zero or the average______________________________ớ.
themeButton.belowMsg: Đ_Emphasize data below a key value like zero or the average______________________________ớ.
themeButton.newToOldMsg: Đ_Vary the size of features from new to old______________________ớ.
themeButton.beforeMsg: Đ_Emphasize data before a key date__________________ớ.
themeButton.afterMsg: Đ_Emphasize data after a key date_________________ớ.

color.aboveAndBelowMsg: Đ_Show data above and below a value like zero or the average_______________________________ớ.
color.centeredMsg: Đ_Center on and highlight a particular range of values____________________________ớ.
color.beforeAndAfterMsg: Đ_Show dates before and after a given date______________________ớ.

methodButton.naturalBreaksMsg: Đ_Create classes based on the natural grouping of the data______________________________ớ.
methodButton.standardDeviationMsg: Đ_Create classes above and below the mean using the standard deviation____________________________________ớ.
methodButton.quantileMsg: Đ_Create classes with the same number of features_________________________ớ.
methodButton.definedIntervalMsg: Đ_Create classes with given interval width______________________ớ.

defaultSymbol.showDefaultSymbolClassed: Đ_Show features with out of range or no values_______________________ớ
defaultSymbol.label: Đ_Label___________ớ

stretchTypeOptionDescriptions.none: Đ_Displays values between the potential minimum and maximum______________________________ớ.
stretchTypeOptionDescriptions.minimumMaximum: Đ_Displays values between the actual minimum and maximum_____________________________ớ.
stretchTypeOptionDescriptions.percentClip: Đ_Cut off percentages of highest and lowest values__________________________ớ.
stretchTypeOptionDescriptions.standardDeviation: Đ_Displays values between a specified number of standard deviations__________________________________ớ.

relationshipFocusButton.focusNoneMsg: Đ_The legend is a square with no focus on a particular corner_______________________________ớ.
relationshipFocusButton.focusHighHighMsg: Đ_The legend is a diamond, focusing on features with high values for both fields_________________________________________ớ.
relationshipFocusButton.focusHighLowMsg: Đ_The legend is a diamond, focusing on features with high values in the first field and low values in the second field____________________________________________________________ớ.
relationshipFocusButton.focusLowHighMsg: Đ_The legend is a diamond, focusing on features with low values in the first and high values in the second field_________________________________________________________ớ.
relationshipFocusButton.focusLowLowMsg: Đ_The legend is a diamond, focusing on features with low values for both fields________________________________________ớ.
